articles.headline: In Restive Chinese Area, Cameras Keep Watch
articles.snippet: Video surveillance is growing explosively in northwestern China, where ethnic Han and Uighur groups took part in the ethnic rioting last year.
articles.abstract: Video surveillance is growing explosively in northwestern China, where ethnic Han and Uighur groups took part in the ethnic rioting last year.
articles.lead_paragraph: URUMQI, China  For a street whose name suggests throwing off shackles, South Liberation Road doesn’t look like a very free place these days.

articles.headline: 99 Weeks Later, Jobless Have Only Desperation
articles.snippet: A tough job market is swelling the ranks of those who have exhausted the maximum 99 weeks of benefits.
articles.abstract: A tough job market is swelling the ranks of those who have exhausted the maximum 99 weeks of benefits.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRATTLEBORO, Vt.  Facing eviction from her Tennessee apartment after several months of unpaid rent, Alexandra Jarrin packed up whatever she could fit into her two-door coupe recently and drove out of town.

articles.headline: Audit Finds Problems in Cattlemen’s Spending
articles.snippet: A cattle industry group improperly used marketing money, raised from ranchers and farmers, to support its lobbying arm, a review found.
articles.abstract: A cattle industry group improperly used marketing money, raised from ranchers and farmers, to support its lobbying arm, a review found.
articles.lead_paragraph: An influential cattle industry group misused money raised from ranchers and farmers for promoting beef sales and violated federal rules by spending some of it to support lobbying activities, according to an outside financial review.

articles.headline: For Data, Tug Grows Over Privacy vs. Security
articles.snippet: Communications companies and governments are struggling to balance privacy with national security.
articles.abstract: Communications companies and governments are struggling to balance privacy with national security.
articles.lead_paragraph: The threat by the United Arab Emirates to shut down mobile services on BlackBerrys like e-mail and text messaging underscores a growing tension between communications companies and governments over how to balance privacy with national security.

articles.headline: Resistance Forms Against Hollywood’s 3-D Push
articles.snippet: Several influential directors have criticized 3-D films, but the audiences — and profits — keep growing.
articles.abstract: Several influential directors have criticized 3-D films, but the audiences — and profits — keep growing.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — A joke making the rounds online involves a pair of red and green glasses and some blurry letters that say, “If you can’t make it good, make it 3-D.”

articles.headline: Audio Pioneer Buys Newsweek
articles.snippet: Sidney Harman, a 91-year-old audio pioneer, will be the new owner of Newsweek, The Washington Post Company announced after a two-and-a-half-month search.
articles.abstract: Sidney Harman, a 91-year-old audio pioneer, will be the new owner of Newsweek, The Washington Post Company announced after a two-and-a-half-month search.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sidney Harman, a 91-year-old audio pioneer, will be the new owner of Newsweek, the Washington Post Company announced on Monday after a two-and-a-half-month search.
articles.byline: By Tanzina Vega and Jeremy W. Peters

articles.headline: Hungary Lays Blame for a Fiscal Crisis on Its Central Bank
articles.snippet: Hungary’s new prime minister, who is bucking the trend of austerity in Europe, is laying blame for economic contraction on the head of its central bank.
articles.abstract: Hungary’s new prime minister, who is bucking the trend of austerity in Europe, is laying blame for economic contraction on the head of its central bank.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s not easy being a central banker in Europe  especially during the biggest economic crisis in a generation.

articles.headline: Punishing Citi, or Its Shareholders?
articles.snippet: The S.E.C. settlement with Citigroup looks like a victory for the good guys, but the bank’s shareholders are really the ones paying the $75 million fine.
articles.abstract: The S.E.C. settlement with Citigroup looks like a victory for the good guys, but the bank’s shareholders are really the ones paying the $75 million fine.
articles.lead_paragraph: Is this really what we mean by holding Wall Street accountable?

articles.headline: For Congress, a New Vigilance in Policing Ethics
articles.snippet: The ethics charges against two House members reflect Washington’s heightened sensitivity to indiscretions.
articles.abstract: The ethics charges against two House members reflect Washington’s heightened sensitivity to indiscretions.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  In the bazaar that is Capitol Hill, there is nothing surprising about lawmakers’ doing favors for campaign donors or intervening with federal agencies on behalf of constituents or friends.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton and Eric Lichtblau
